title: 109_hr4079
content: The "Secure Our Nation's Interior Act of 2005" may be cited as the short title. It includes provisions for expedited removal. Section 235(b)(1)(A) of the Immigration and Nationality Act is amended to specify conditions for determining inadmissibility of arriving aliens in the United States. The determination of inadmissibility under this paragraph results in removal from the United States without further hearing or review, unless the alien is involved in criminal proceedings or indicates an intention to apply for asylum or fear of persecution. If an alien arriving in the United States indicates an intention to apply for asylum or fear of persecution, they will be referred for an interview by an asylum officer if they have been in the country for less than 1 year. State and local law enforcement personnel have the authority to enforce immigration laws and detain or transfer aliens to federal custody. This authority is not overridden by Congress. The Department of Homeland Security can respond to requests for assistance from state and local law enforcement regarding the custody of illegal aliens. If the Governor of a State requests the Secretary of Homeland Security to take an illegal alien into Federal custody, the Secretary must do so within 48 hours. Alternatively, the Secretary can ask the relevant State or local law enforcement agency to temporarily hold the alien for transfer to Federal custody. The Secretary of Homeland Security must transfer illegal aliens to Federal custody within 48 hours if requested by a State Governor. Reimbursement will be provided to States and localities for expenses incurred in the incarceration and transportation of illegal aliens. The Secretary of Homeland Security must ensure that illegal aliens incarcerated in Federal facilities are held in secure facilities. Additionally, reimbursement for costs incurred in the incarceration and transportation of illegal aliens will be provided to States and localities. The Secretary of Homeland Security may establish a circuit for transferring illegal aliens from State custody to Federal custody. Agreements can be made with State and local law enforcement for implementation. The term 'illegal alien' refers to those who entered the US without inspection or at unauthorized locations. SEC. 5. UNIVERSAL PROCESSING THROUGH THE AUTOMATED ENTRY-EXIT CONTROL SYSTEM. SEC. 5. UNIVERSAL PROCESSING THROUGH THE AUTOMATED ENTRY-EXIT CONTROL SYSTEM. Amends the Illegal Immigration Reform and Immigrant Responsibility Act of 1996 to collect and maintain a record of each admission for every alien arriving in the United States, verify the identity of every arriving and departing alien. Amends the Immigration and Nationality Act to require the verification of the identity of all arriving and departing aliens through a biometric identifier on their travel documents. All aliens seeking admission to the United States must be inspected by immigration officers. The Immigration and Nationality Act now mandates that all aliens entering or re-entering the United States must go through the automated entry-exit control system. A report detailing the resources needed for full implementation must be submitted to Congress within 90 days of the Act's enactment.
